Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: Sequential Monte Carlo Methods for High Dimensional Systems
Abstract

Advances in the development of models and methods that can satisfactorily describe and analyze high dimensional systems are extremely valuable for many different disciplines including biology, meteorology, economics,social sciences, and engineering. These systems are characterized by nonlinearities and are difficult to understand.Computational methods governed by simple local rules have the potential of providing insightful interpretations
and of paving the way towards quantitative and qualitative descriptions and understanding of complex systems.This project is focused on development of such methods and in particular on the development of a synergistic research and educational program in sequential Monte Carlo-based signal processing for high dimensional systems.

This research aims at laying the foundations of a sequential Monte Carlo methodology for high dimensional systems. In the literature, there are claims stating that particle filters cannot be used for complex systems because their random measures degenerate to single particles. While this is true for standard implementation of these filters, it does not hold true for alternative approaches. A new methodology based on the principle of divide and conquer is developed. In particular, the collapse of traditional particle filltering is avoided by setting an interconnected network of filters, each of them working on lower dimensional spaces. Research tasks include development of the theoretical grounds of the methods, establishment of guidelines for its use by practitioners,analysis of its accuracy, stability and scalability, and validation on a wide range of complex systems. The proposed methods are original and provide solutions to arguably the biggest open problem of particle filtering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In signal processing, all the information about unknowns is contained in their posterior distributions. The unknowns can be parameters of a model, or a model and its parameters. In many important problems, these distributions are basically impossible to obtain in analytical forms. An alternative is to generate an approximation of these distributions by Monte Carlo-based methods like Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling, adaptive importance sampling (AIS) or particle filtering (PF). In the literature, there are claims stating that particle filters cannot be used for complex systems because their random measures degenerate to single particles. While this is true for standard implementation of these filters, it does not hold true for alternative approaches.

 

With this project, we researched a new methodology based on the principle of divide and conquer where the collapse of traditional PF is avoided by setting an interconnected network of filters, each of them working on lower dimensional spaces. Over the duration of this project, there were many issues that were investigated, and they included the partitioning of the state space depending on the nature of the problem; communication strategies among the particle filters; convergence of the methods; study of the accuracy of the results; and application of the new theories to different problems (e.g. cancer spheroid formation, prediction of finantial data, ECG denoising, or tracking with RFID systems).

 

Significant results of the project included new PF methods for complex systems implemented through various algorithms of reduced complexity as well as studies of the methods’ convergence and robustness. Moreover, this effort resulted in extensions of the proposed methodology to high dimensional systems characterized by batch setups as well as to scenarios where there is no knowledge about the underlying probabilistic model.  The impact of these theoretical results was shown in a large range of applications and disciplines including the modeling and simulation of complex biological systems describing the evolution of cancer stem cells into tumors,  target tracking in mobile sensor networks and in the presence of dynamic interferes, accurate real time indoor tracking of tagged objects in UHF RFID systems, inference in gene networks, prediction of influenza rates, and prediction in financial applications. In addition to the theoretical and practical research achievements, other outcomes included educational activities at the high-school, undergraduate and graduate levels, publication of papers in journals and conferences, and talks given at institutions and at research meetings.
